lg.l: Strenuus & fortis &c.
Harley! the Nation·s great support
Returning home one day from Court
His mind with public cares possest
All Europes busines in his breast
Observ'd a Parson near whitehall
Cheapning old Authors on a stall
The Priest was pretty well in case
And shew'd some hum·ur in his face
Look·d with an easy careles mien
A perfect stranger to ye Spleen
Of size that might a Pulpit fill
But more inclining to sitt still
My Lord who if a man may say it
Loves mischeifs better than his meat
Was now dispos'd to crack a jest
And bid friend Lewis go in quest
(This Lewis is a cunning Shaver)
And very much in Harleys favour)
In quest, who might this Parson be
What was his name of what degree
If possible to learn his story
And whether he were whig or Tory
Lewis his Patrons humour knows
Away upon his Errand goes
And quickly did ye matter sift
Found out that this was Dr S────t
A Clergyman of special note
For shunning those of his own coat
Which made his brethren of ye gown
Take care betimes to run him down
No Libertine nor over nice
Addicted to no Sort of Vice
Went where he pleas'd said what he thought
Not rich but ow·d no man a groat.
In state opinions a la mode
He hated Wha·ton like a toad
Had given the faction many a wound
And libell'd all ye junto round
Kept company with men of wit
Who often fatherd what he writ
His works were hawkd in every street
But seldom rose above a sheet
Of late indeed the Paper stamp
Did very much his glories cramp
And since he could not spend his fire
He now intended to retire.
Said Harley, I desire to know
From his own mouth, if this be so
Step to yẹ Doctor straight & say
I'd have him dine with me to day
S──seem'd to wonder what he meant
Nor would beleive my Ld had sent
So never offer'd once to stir
But coldly said, Yr Servant Sir
Does he refuse me? Harley cry'ed
He does with insolence & pride
Some few days after Harley spies
The Doctor Fasten'd by ye. eyes
At Charing cros among ye rout
Where painted monsters are hung out
He pull'd ye String & stopt his coach
Beckning ye Doctor to approach
S──who could neither Flye nor hide
Came sneaking to ye Chariot side
And offer'd overed many a lame excuse
He never meant ye least abuse────
My Lord──The Honour You design'd
Extremely proud──but I had din'd────
I·am sure I never shoud neglect────
No man alive has more respect────
Well I shal think of that no more
If You'l be sure to come at four
The Dr now obeys ye summons
Likes both his company & commons
Displays his Talent sits till ten
Next day invited, comes again──
Soon grows domestic seldom Failes
Either at morning or at meals
Came early & departed late
In short──The Gudgeon took ye Bait
My Ld would carry on ye jest
And down to Windsor takes his Guest
S──much admires the place & aire
And longs to be a Canon there
In Summer round the Park to ride
In Winter never to reside
A Canon, thats a place too mean
No Doctor You shall be a Dean.
Two dozen Canons round yr Stall
And You the Tyrant ore them all
You need but cros ye Irish seas
To live in plenty power & ease.Poor S────departs, & what is worse
With borrow'd mony in his purse
Travels at least an hundred leagues
And Suffers numberles fatigues.
Suppose him now a Dean compleat
Devoutly lolling in his seat
The silver Verge with decent pride
Stuck underneath his cushion side
Suppose him gon thro all vexations
Patents, instalments abjurations
First fruits & Tenths & Chapter Treats
Dues payments Fees, demands & cheats
The wicked Layetys cntriving
To hinder Clergymen from thriving
Now all ye Drs mony's spent
His Tenants wrong him in his rent
The Farmers spitefully combin'd
Force him to take his Tythes in kind
And 1The Deans Agent A French man. Parvisol discounts arrears
By bills for taxes & repairs.
Poor S──with all his losses vext
Not knowing where to turn him next
Above a thousand pounds in debt
Takes Horse & in a mighty Fret
Rides day and night at such a rate
He soon arrives at Harleys Gate
But was so dirty pale & thin
Old Read would hardly let him in
Said Harley Welcome Reverend Dean.
What makes Yr worship look so lean
Why sure you wont appear in town
With that old wig & rusty gown
I doubt yr heart is set on pelfe
So much, yt You neglect Yr Selfe
What! I suppose now stocks are high
You've some good purchase in yr eye
Or is Your mony out at use────
Truce Good my Ld I beg a truce
The Dṛ in a passion cry'd
Yr Raillery is misapply'd
I have experience dearly bought
You know I am not worth a groat
But You resolv'd to have Yr jest
And twas a folly to contest
Then since you now have done Yr worst,
Pray leave me where you found me first.170-112B
